Subject: Re: Question about Novelty Search
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=130984297; y=k9ZXs92BiKfSsqlTiB2vF7ilQvJoUueq_u6cULZK-EnHnDPUvjsL
X-Yahoo-Profile: joel278

Ken,

I don't think that speciation in novelty search is much different fro=
m
fitness, but I was exploring why it might be possible to get good
results=
 in the maze domain with static novelties (which seems, to me
at least, lik=
e an unprincipled method).

Speciation in NEAT provides a solution for comp=
eting conventions,
protects innovation in the genotype space, and may bias =
the search
towards promising genotypic lineages (species with highly fit
in=
dividuals get more resources). Running NEAT on a domain that is not
co-evol=
utionary, the fitness of an individual will stay the same, and
a good indiv=
idual will continually benefit its species. However, in a
co-evolutionary d=
omain, the fitness landscape is ever changing, and a
once-promising individ=
ual may soon be seen as low-fitness with no
benefit to its species (this is=
 especially true in novelty search). So
the bias towards promising genotypi=
c lines seems to be less in novelty
search. This could be a good thing, mea=
ning a less greedy search, and
the assumption that a certain genotypic line=
 is more predisposed to
leading to novelty may not be warranted. 

But if y=
ou use static novelties, then it seems as if species that once
created nove=
lty are continually rewarded, once again biasing the
search towards promisi=
ng lineages. If this is an important facet of
speciation, then maybe a more=
 explicit way of rewarding it would work
better than the ad-hoc static nove=
lties approach (e.g. award a species
a certain bonus in proportion to the h=
ighest novelty it has found). I
am not convinced that this lineage bias is =
important, but I think it
bears further thought.

So I think there is a dif=
ference in the effects of speciation on
co-evolutionary tasks with highly v=
ariable fitness landscapes and on
tasks with static fitness landscapes, but=
 perhaps this is what we do
want in those kinds of landscapes.

Joel

--- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Are the=
se issues regarding speciation in novelty search really any
> different fro=
m the very same issues in fitness-based search?  I am
> still thinking abou=
t this issue, but I am not sure they are really
> different.
> 
> In NEAT-b=
ased novelty search, speciation is still happening as normal.
>  One thing =
speciation does in fitness-based search is protect unique
> individuals who=
 may have lower fitness based on the idea that they may
> take a while to r=
each their potential.  By analogy, in novelty search,
> the effect is to pr=
otect genetically unique individuals who may not be
> very novel behavioral=
ly on the chance that they too may need some time
> to discover how to do s=
omething novel.
> 
> In other words, speciation means less greedy search.  =
In some cases,
> of course, being less greedy means being slower (such as w=
hen there is
> a single global optimum on a giant hill across the entire se=
arch
> space).  In particular, if the most fit (or most novel) individuals
=
> for whatever reason turn out to be the best jumping-off points for
> even=
 more fit (or more novel) individuals, then the time spent on
> protected i=
ndividuals was "wasted."  Yet that would not be the case in
> all domains, =
so to forego such protection is to take a risk in general.
> 
> It could be=
 that in the maze domain a greedier kind of novelty search
> would be faste=
r.  But would that be true in other domains?  An
> interesting question is =
the extent to which novelty search is better
> served by greediness than fi=
tness-based search.  I am not sure if
> there is any basis to believe that =
it is.
> 
> The idea of taking species age into account might be interestin=
g, but
> the question is still why this consideration would matter more or =
less
> than in fitness-based NEAT?
> 
> Overall, the way I see speciation i=
nteracting with novelty search is
> to protect small species that have uniq=
ue genotypes even if those do
> not translate to novel behaviors in the hop=
e that unique genotypes may
> have the potential to turn into unique behavi=
ors if given the chance. 
> 
> It is possible that I am misinterpreting the=
 idea that you guys are
> developing, so please do clarify my comments if t=
hat is the case. 
> Novelty search does challenge a lot of common assumptio=
ns about search.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervens=
ki" <petar_chervenski@>
> wrote:
> >
> > Yes, I believe so. Perhaps somethi=
ng similar to the niching mechanism 
> > in generational NEAT, boosting you=
nger species's fitness and 
> > penalizing old species. In Novelty Search t=
his may be applied like.. 
> > If a species continiously produces novel for=
ms, it is rewarded. If a 
> > species keeps prodicing the same or close to =
the same known 
> > behaviors, then it can be penalized. 
> > 
> > Peter
> =

d point, that perhaps the fitness of the individuals is
> > > not as import=
ant as that of the overall species, since that will
> > > determine the amo=
unt of offspring a particular species gets.
> > > 
> > > So the bias then i=
s to genotypic lines that have produced novelty in
> > > the past, which mi=
ght be a good indicator of novelty in the future.
> > > Maybe there is a wa=
y to reward species in a more principled/explicit
> > > manner? 
> > >

rote:

It seems like never changing the 
> > novelty
> > > > scores would create a=
ttractors around old behaviors instead of new
> > > ones. 
> > > > 
> > > >=
 For example, imagine an individual that reaches a new area in
> > > > beha=
vioral space. It is assigned a high novelty score. Several new
> > > > indi=
viduals arrive in the same area, and get lower novelty scores 
> > (the
> >=
 > > first one maintains its high score). What we want is to explore 
> > t=
he
> > > > individuals on the 'fringe' of this new area, in hopes of findin=
g
> > > > further areas of novetly. However, with constant novelty scores, =

> > the
> > > > bias will be to investigate the area in the proximity of t=
he first
> > > > individual, even though the ones on the fringe may be more=
 
> > promising.
> > > > 
> > > > If you consistently get better performanc=
e with constant novelty
> > > > scores over a variety of maps perhaps it is=
 worth looking into 
> > more.
> > > > 
> > > > Joel

al.

ividual in the

n our implementation it is

s

ndividuals in behavior

sly was. As more individuals come

> > > > > > particular area, =
the novelty of all of them drops, and

> > > > > > pressure fo=
r individuals to do something new in order to be

> > > > > no=
vel.
